newsitem.title: POLAND: POLISH CABINET ACCEPTS DEAL WITH VATICAN ON TREATY.
newsitem.headline: POLISH CABINET ACCEPTS DEAL WITH VATICAN ON TREATY.

text.p: Poland's cabinet on Tuesday approved a compromise with the Vatican which may lead the parliament, dominated by ex-communists, to at last approve a treaty with the Apostolic See signed in 1993.

At a cabinet meeting in Warsaw, Prime Minister Wlodzimierz Cimoszewicz signed a declaration clearing up controversial or unclear issues which had held up the concordat treaty's ratification by Polish legislators.

"I want publicly to express satisfaction that after many months of negotiations with...the Apostolic See, the contents were agreed of the declaration which the Polish government accepted today," Cimoszewicz told reporters.
Parliament's refusal to ratify the treaty, which was signed by a previous pro-Catholic centre-right government just before losing elections in 1993, has long been a contentious issue.

If unresolved, it threatened to cast a shadow over Pope John Paul's May 31-June 10 visit to his homeland and be a key rallying point for the rightist opposition grouped around the pro-Church Solidarity union at September parliamentary polls.
Ex-Communist President Aleksander Kwasniewski, who visited the Pope this month, and Poland's foreign minister both argued for ratification, partly to show that Poland honoured treaties.
Members of the ruling ex-communist Democratic Left Alliance (SLD) have argued that the concordat, regulating church-state relations, risked giving the church undue influence.
They refused to approve it, at least until after a new Polish constitution was in place setting out religion's role.
Solidarity chiefs said this reflected deep anti-clericalism among ex-communists who persecuted the church in the past.
After years of debate since the 1989 fall of communism, a new constitution has been agreed by parliamentary parties and is due to be subjected to a popular referendum on May 25.
It is opposed by Solidarity partly because its world-view is too secular, but if it passes, the constitution will help clear the way for the concordat to be clinched.
The document approved on Tuesday is a unilateral Polish declaration but was settled in long secret negotiations with the Vatican and has the force of an agreement.
Among issues which is settles are an undertaking that the Catholic church will not start to refuse burial in Catholic cemeteries to people of other faiths or none.
Civil and religious marriages will have the same legal status and priests providing voluntary religious education in state schools will be treated like other staff and paid.
Cimoszewicz said that it made clear that specific questions would be regulated by Polish law, without infringing the sovereign powers of parliament or government.
He said the declaration would be sent later on Tuesday to parliament for inclusion in a legislative package ratifying the concordat.
Earlier he told a radio interviewer that parliament may be ready to vote on ratification in late May or early June -- at the time of the Pope's visit.
